title: 114_hr6447
content: The "Protecting Our Democracy Act" establishes the National Commission on Foreign Interference in the 2016 Election with the purpose of investigating foreign interference in the election. The National Commission on Foreign Interference in the 2016 Election will examine Russian government activities to influence US elections in 2016 through electronic hacks on Democratic organizations and individuals. The National Commission on Foreign Interference in the 2016 Election will investigate Russian government efforts to influence the 2016 US elections through electronic hacks on Democratic organizations, individuals, and voter databases in Arizona, Illinois, and Florida. Additionally, the Commission will examine Russian government attempts to spread false news about the election campaigns and collaborate with other governments, entities, and individuals to interfere in the elections. The Commission's purpose is to investigate attempts by governments, entities, and individuals other than the Russian government to use electronic means to influence or interfere with US elections in 2016. The Commission is tasked with investigating attempts to influence US elections in 2016 using electronic means. The Commission, composed of 12 members appointed by various leaders, will choose a Chair and Vice Chair from its members. Qualifications require appointees to not be government officials. The Commission, composed of 12 members appointed by various leaders, will choose a Chair and Vice Chair from its members. Members should be prominent US citizens with expertise in professions like governmental service, law enforcement, armed services, law, public administration, intelligence gathering, foreign affairs, cybersecurity, and Federal elections. All members must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment, vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and members may receive compensation. Each member of the Commission may be compensated at a daily rate not exceeding the annual rate of basic pay for a position at level IV of the Executive Schedule. They are also allowed travel expenses while performing Commission duties. Allowed expenses under section 5703(b) of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 5. PROCEDURES OF COMMISSION. The Commission shall meet promptly after its initial meeting, with sessions called by the chairman or majority members. A majority of members constitutes a quorum, but for testimony, 2 members can suffice if one is appointed under each section. Proxy voting is not allowed, and the Commission will establish rules of procedure. The Commission shall establish rules for its business, to be adopted at the initial meeting. The Commission shall establish rules for its business at the initial meeting. The Commission's duties include investigating Russian attempts to influence US elections in 2016 through electronic means, such as hacks into the Democratic National Committee and Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee systems. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, John Podesta's electronic systems, Colin Powell's electronic systems, and voter database information from Arizona, Illinois, and Florida were targeted. Efforts by the Russian government and entities associated with Russia to spread false news about the 2016 US election campaigns were also investigated. The 2016 US election saw efforts by the Russian government and other entities to influence the election through electronic means. The investigation also aimed to learn from these activities and identify lessons. The Commission aims to detect, prevent, protect from, and respond to foreign attempts to influence US elections through electronic means. Recommendations will be made to prevent future interference. Interim and final reports will be submitted to the President and Congress within 18 months. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress within 18 months, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations agreed upon by a majority of members. SEC. 7. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission, subcommittees, or members can hold hearings, take testimony, and require witnesses and documents through subpoenas. Subpoenas can only be issued with the agreement of the Chair and Vice Chair. Subpoenas issued by the Commission can be enforced through the United States district court in case of non-compliance. Subpoenas require the agreement of the Chair or a majority of the Commission members for issuance and can be served by individuals designated by the Chair or Commission members. The Commission can enforce subpoenas through the United States district court for non-compliance. Failure to obey a court order may result in contempt charges. In cases of witness non-compliance, the Commission can certify the failure to the US attorney for possible grand jury action. The Commission can enter into contracts to fulfill its duties and obtain information from federal agencies for the purposes of the Act. The Commission can request information directly from federal agencies, which must be handled and disseminated in accordance with laws and regulations. The General Services Administration will provide administrative support to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission can request assistance from other departments and agencies of the United States for services, funds, facilities, staff, and support services as authorized by law. The Commission is also allowed to use the United States mails like other government entities. The Commission is authorized to request assistance from other departments and agencies of the United States for staff. The chairman of the Commission may appoint a staff director and necessary personnel without following certain regulations, with a maximum pay rate equivalent to level V of the Executive Schedule. The staff director and personnel are considered federal employees. The Commission's staff director and employees are considered federal employees under specific sections of the United States Code. Members of the Commission are not included in this classification. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and retain their regular employment rights. The Commission can procure expert and consultant services at rates not exceeding those specified in the United States Code. The Commission can procure expert and consultant services under section 3109 of title 5, United States Code, at rates not exceeding those for a person at level IV of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 9. The Commission must hold public meetings and release public versions of reports. Public hearings must protect sensitive information. SEC. 10. Commission members and staff must have security clearances. SEC. 10. Security clearances provided to Commission members and staff by Federal agencies. No access to classified information without appropriate clearances. SEC. 11. Commission terminates 60 days after final report submission. May conclude activities and disseminate final report during this period. SEC. 12. Funding provisions. SEC. 12. FUNDING. $3,000,000 authorized for this Act. Amounts available until Commission termination. SEC. 13. Definition of "electronic systems" as computers, servers, and electronic communications.
